message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of hypovolemic shock, with low blood pressure and diffusely tender abdomen. A diagnostic peritoneal lavage is the best next step to assess for intra-abdominal bleeding, as it is minimally invasive and can be performed quickly in the emergency department. Abdominal CT may be performed afterwards for further evaluation. Diagnostic laparoscopy or emergency laparotomy may be necessary if there is clear evidence of intra-abdominal bleeding or organ injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is hypotensive and has diffuse abdominal tenderness. Given the mechanism of injury and the physical findings, the most likely diagnosis is internal bleeding. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the bleeding. CT may also be used, but it is less sensitive than DPL in detecting small amounts of blood. Diagnostic laparoscopy and emergency laparotomy can be considered if DPL is inconclusive or if there is evidence of significant bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of abdominal trauma with diffuse tenderness and bruising, but the FAST exam is equivocal, suggesting further evaluation is needed. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is a minimally invasive option that can help determine if there is intra-abdominal bleeding. Emergency laparotomy is more invasive and should be reserved for cases of known or suspected active bleeding. Abdominal CT and diagnostic laparoscopy are also options but may not be as immediate or definitive as diagnostic peritoneal lavage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s low blood pressure and diffuse abdominal tenderness suggest a possible intra-abdominal injury, making further testing necessary. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is a sensitive test for intra-abdominal bleeding and is often used in unstable patients when other imaging modalities are not feasible. Abdominal CT may be the next step if DPL is inconclusive, but it is not the best initial step. Diagnostic laparoscopy is not appropriate for unstable patients, and emergency laparotomy is a more invasive option that should be reserved for patients with hemodynamic instability despite resuscitative measures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of hypertension and current hypotension suggests a possible intra-abdominal bleed. A diagnostic peritoneal lavage can help confirm or rule out this diagnosis. Abdominal CT or diagnostic laparoscopy may be options as well, but diagnostic peritoneal lavage is quicker and less invasive. Emergency laparotomy would be too invasive without confirmation of intra-abdominal bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's unstable blood pressure and diffuse abdominal tenderness suggest a possible intra-abdominal bleed. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) can help confirm this diagnosis and guide further management. Abdominal CT may be useful but takes more time and radiation exposure. Diagnostic laparoscopy and emergency laparotomy may be required depending on the findings of the DPL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible intra-abdominal injury, and the equivocal FAST exam suggests further evaluation is necessary. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is a minimally invasive technique that can help determine if there is intra-abdominal bleeding, and is the best next step in this scenario. Abdominal CT and diagnostic laparoscopy can also provide further information, but require more time and resources. Emergency laparotomy should be considered only if the patient’s condition deteriorates rapidly and there is suspicion of massive intra-abdominal bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s low blood pressure and abdominal tenderness suggests intra-abdominal bleeding. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis, as it is a rapid diagnostic test that can identify intra-abdominal bleeding. Abdominal CT can also be performed but may take longer to obtain and may not be as sensitive as DPL. Diagnostic laparoscopy and emergency laparotomy are invasive procedures and should only be considered if DPL is inconclusive or if the patient’s condition deteriorates rapidly.

We refer to PubMed Health for help. The patient’s history and physical examination are suggestive of intra-abdominal bleeding. The FAST exam is equivocal and the patient’s blood pressure did not improve despite receiving intravenous fluids. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is considered the next best step in evaluating for intra-abdominal bleeding. Abdominal CT, diagnostic laparoscopy, and emergency laparotomy may be indicated depending on the results of diagnostic peritoneal lavage.

We refer to the Medscape article "Abdominal Trauma" for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam are suggestive of possible internal bleeding, and the initial fluid resuscitation did not improve her blood pressure. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is the next best step to evaluate for intraabdominal bleeding. Abdominal CT may be an option in stable patients, but the patient is hemodynamically unstable. Diagnostic laparoscopy and emergency laparotomy are not indicated at this time.
